The study was to evaluate the ability of a novel activatable magnetic resonance imaging nanoprobe, to target MMPs in an Angiotensin II- induced AAA model.”.
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx
Cardiovascular Daily \-- Current study results on Cardiovascular Diseases and
Conditions - Aortic Aneurysm have been published. According to news reporting
originating in Stanford, California, by NewsRx journalists, research stated,
"Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) activation contributes to abdominal aortic
aneurysm (AAA) growth and rupture. The study was to evaluate the ability of a
novel activatable magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) nanoprobe, to target MMPs
in an Angiotensin II (ANG II)-induced AAA model."

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from the Stanford
University School of Medicine, "The activatable nanoprobe is composed of a
hydrophilic polyethylene glycol coating layer immobilized on the external
surface of core/shell Fe/iron oxide nanoparticles; between them, there was
grafted the MMP peptide substrate. In the ANG II infusion mice model of AAAs,
MRI was performed to characterize the progression of model. The contrast-to-
noise ratio was lower in the aneurysm of the mice injected with activatable
nanoprobe. Histological studies revealed the presence of MMPs and iron-oxide
in regions of MR signal decrease."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "MRI combined with
nanoprobe allows the detection of MMP activity within the wall of AAA, thus
representing a potential noninvasive method to predict the rupture risk of
AAA."

For more information on this research see: Evaluation of a smart activatable
MRI nanoprobe to target matrix metalloproteinases in the early-stages of
abdominal aortic aneurysms. _Nanomedicine_ , 2020;26():102177. (Elsevier \-
[www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com); Nanomedicine -
<http://www.journals.elsevier.com/nanomedicine-nanotechnology-biology-and-
medicine/>)

Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting K. Cheng, Molecular Imaging Program at Stanford, Dept. of Radiology
and Bio-X Program, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA,
United States. Additional authors for this research include Y. Yao and Z.
Cheng.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nano.2020.102177>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Aortic Aneurysm Study Findings Have Been Reported by Researchers at Stanford University School of Medicine (Evaluation of a smart activatable MRI nanoprobe to target matrix metalloproteinases in the early-stages of abdominal aortic aneurysms): Cardiovascular Diseases and Conditions - Aortic Aneurysm
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Cardiovascular Daily -- Current study results on Cardiovascular Diseases and Conditions - Aortic Aneurysm have been published. According to news reporting originating in Stanford, California, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) activation contributes to abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) growth and rupture. The study was to evaluate the ability of a novel activatable magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) nanoprobe, to target MMPs in an Angiotensin II (ANG II)-induced AAA model.”

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from the Stanford University School of Medicine, “The activatable nanoprobe is composed of a hydrophilic polyethylene glycol coating layer immobilized on the external surface of core/shell Fe/iron oxide nanoparticles; between them, there was grafted the MMP peptide substrate. In the ANG II infusion mice model of AAAs, MRI was performed to characterize the progression of model. The contrast-to-noise ratio was lower in the aneurysm of the mice injected with activatable nanoprobe. Histological studies revealed the presence of MMPs and iron-oxide in regions of MR signal decrease.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “MRI combined with nanoprobe allows the detection of MMP activity within the wall of AAA, thus representing a potential noninvasive method to predict the rupture risk of AAA.”

For more information on this research see: Evaluation of a smart activatable MRI nanoprobe to target matrix metalloproteinases in the early-stages of abdominal aortic aneurysms. Nanomedicine, 2020;26():102177. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Nanomedicine - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/nanomedicine-nanotechnology-biology-and-medicine/)

Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting K. Cheng, Molecular Imaging Program at Stanford, Dept. of Radiology and Bio-X Program, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, United States. Additional authors for this research include Y. Yao and Z. Cheng.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nano.2020.102177. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
